$(this).find('.icon-general-add, .icon-minus').toggleClass('icon-minus icon-general-add');\r\n            $(this).siblings('.ati-toggle-content').toggleClass('hide');\r\n        });\r\n\r\n        // In Chrome, an anchor tag with target=\"_blank\" and a \"mailto:\" href opens a new tab/window as well as the email client\r\n        // I suspect this behavior will be corrected in the future\r\n        // Remove the target=\"_blank\"\r\n        $('ul.wi-affiliationList').find('a[href^=\"mailto:\"]').each(function () {\r\n            $(this).removeAttr('target');\r\n        });\r\n    });\r\n</script>\r\n\r\n \n    </div>\n    <div class=\"widget widget-ArticleLinks widget-instance-OUP_Article_Links_Widget\">\n         \n    </div>\n\r\n\r\n        <div class=\"article-body <div class=\"widget widget-ArticleFulltext widget-instance-OUP_Article_FullText_Widget\">\n        <div class=\"module-widget\">\r\n    <div class=\"widget-items\" data-widgetname=\"ArticleFulltext\">\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n                    <h2 scrollto-destination=130796726 id=\"130796726\" class=\"abstract-title\" >Abstract</h2>\r\n<section class=\"abstract\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">We search Dark Energy Survey (DES) Year 3 imaging data for galaxy\u2013galaxy strong gravitational lenses using convolutional neural networks. We generate 250\u2009000 simulated lenses at redshifts &gt; 0.8 from which we create a data set for training the neural networks with realistic seeing, sky and shot noise. Using the simulations as a guide, we build a catalogue of 1.1 million DES sources with 1.8 &lt; <em>g</em> \u2212 <em>i</em> &lt; 5, 0.6 &lt; <em>g</em> \u2212 <em>r</em> &lt; 3, <em>r</em>_mag &gt; 19, <em>g</em>_mag &gt; 20, and <em>i</em>_mag &gt; 18.2. We train two ensembles of neural networks on training sets consisting of simulated lenses, simulated non-lenses, and real sources. We use the neural networks to score images of each of the sources in our catalogue with a value from 0 to 1, and select those with scores greater than a chosen threshold for visual inspection, resulting in a candidate set of 7301 galaxies. During visual inspection, we rate 84 as \u2018probably\u2019 or \u2018definitely\u2019 lenses. Four of these are previously known lenses or lens candidates. We inspect a further 9428 candidates with a different score threshold, and identify four new candidates. We present 84 new strong lens candidates, selected after a few hours of visual inspection by astronomers. This catalogue contains a comparable number of high-redshift lenses to that predicted by simulations. Based on simulations, we estimate our sample to contain most discoverable lenses in this imaging and at this redshift range.</p></section>                        <div class=\"article-metadata-panel clearfix\"></div>\r\n<div class=\"kwd-group\"><a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;gravitational lensing: strong&quot;\">gravitational lensing: strong</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;methods: statistical&quot;\">methods: statistical</a></div>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=130796728 id=\"130796728\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec1>1 INTRODUCTION</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Gravitational lensing, a phenomenon arising from the relativistic curvature of space-time around massive objects (Einstein <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib23\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib23\" data-open=\"bib23\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1936</a>; Zwicky <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib80\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib80\" data-open=\"bib80\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1937</a>), is a subject of increasing importance in astrophysics and cosmology. Where a large lensing potential and a close alignment of the lens mass and source coincide, strong lensing can produce highly magnified images of distant sources. When studied, they can serve as a unique probe of both lens and source properties (see Treu <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib74\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib74\" data-open=\"bib74\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a> for an overview). Since the detection of the first strongly lensed quasar in 1979 (Walsh, Carswell\u00a0&amp; Weymann <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib77\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib77\" data-open=\"bib77\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1979</a>) a growing catalogue of strong lenses has been discovered, now numbering in the hundreds.<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn1\" data-open=\"fn1\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">1</a></sup></p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Individual strong lenses can be highly valuable scientifically. By magnifying distant sources by a factor of tens to \u223c100, lensing can allow us to examine sources otherwise too distant to detect, for instance (Stark et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib70\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib70\" data-open=\"bib70\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>; Quider et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib61\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib61\" data-open=\"bib61\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>; Newton et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib56\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib56\" data-open=\"bib56\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>; Zheng et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib79\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib79\" data-open=\"bib79\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; Ebeling et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib22\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib22\" data-open=\"bib22\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>), even a single star at redshift 1.5 (Kelly et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib42\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib42\" data-open=\"bib42\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>). In quantity, strong lenses can be valuable cosmological probes; the many applications include an independent measure of H<sub>0</sub> via time delays between multiply-imaged quasars (Bonvin et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib9\" data-open=\"bib9\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>), or testing Warm Dark Matter models through the statistics of perturbations in a large sample of Einstein rings and arcs (Vegetti et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib76\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib76\" data-open=\"bib76\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; Li et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib49\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib49\" data-open=\"bib49\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>), including by line-of-sight substructure (Despali et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib17\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib17\" data-open=\"bib17\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>). For the latter, lenses at high redshift are particularly valuable.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Because of their high surface mass density, early-type galaxies (ETGs) represent the vast majority of galaxy\u2013galaxy lenses. ETGs contain most of the stellar mass in the local universe, and so an understanding of their star formation and assembly histories is key for building an accurate picture of the evolution of structure in the Universe. Strong lensing can act as a probe of lens mass with precision at great distances, and is thus a crucial tool in understanding the history of these galaxies at early times.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Observations have shown that the total density profiles of elliptical galaxies can be well-described by a power law, with <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\rho (r) \\propto r^{-\\gamma ^{\\prime }}$|\u2060</span>. Observationally, most galaxies demonstrate roughly isothermal profiles, i.e. \u03b3\u2032 \u223c 2; however, reproducing the observed isothermality has proven challenging for simulations. Magneticum and EAGLE simulations both predict slopes significantly shallower than observed in local galaxies (Bellstedt et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib7\" data-open=\"bib7\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>). Simulations also predict that \u03b3\u2032 becomes shallower over time (Remus et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib63\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib63\" data-open=\"bib63\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>), whilst observations suggest the opposite (Sonnenfeld et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib69\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib69\" data-open=\"bib69\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>; Shankar et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib68\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib68\" data-open=\"bib68\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>). This tension implies that our understanding of the mechanisms by which galaxies evolve, such as the role of dissipationless dry mergers at later times, is incomplete. At the present time, the redshift leverage of existing observations is insufficient to settle this question; only five lenses at redshift &gt;0.8 have been available for this analysis.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Locally, the mass density profiles of ETGs have been probed using tools such as stellar dynamics (notably Tim de Zeeuw et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib73\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib73\" data-open=\"bib73\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2002</a>; Cappellari et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib11\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib11\" data-open=\"bib11\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>) and the dynamics of H\u00a0<span class=\"small-caps\">i</span> gas regions (e.g. Weijmans et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib78\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib78\" data-open=\"bib78\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>) and globular clusters (e.g. Oldham\u00a0&amp; Auger <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib59\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib59\" data-open=\"bib59\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>); however, beyond the local universe, lensing is the most practical tool. The Einstein radius of a lens system is an observable quantity and is proportional to the mass within that radius; combined with a measurement of velocity dispersion and source and lens redshifts, a robust measurement of the Einstein radius can constrain \u03b3\u2032, the mean total density slope, to under 5\u00a0per\u2009cent (Treu\u00a0&amp; Koopmans <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib75\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib75\" data-open=\"bib75\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2004</a>; Treu <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib74\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib74\" data-open=\"bib74\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>; Ruff et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib65\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib65\" data-open=\"bib65\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>). This analysis has been carried out at local redshifts, for instance by Collier, Smith\u00a0&amp; Lucey (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib16\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib16\" data-open=\"bib16\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>) (two galaxies at <em>z</em> = 0.03 and <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.05); on 16 Sloan Lens ACS Survey (SLACS) galaxies in the redshift range 0.08\u20130.33 by Barnab\u00e8 et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib6\" data-open=\"bib6\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>); and on 25 Strong Lensing Legacy Survey (SL2S) galaxies at redshifts 0.2\u20130.8 by Sonnenfeld et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib69\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib69\" data-open=\"bib69\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>), constraining \u03b3\u2032 to \u223c5\u00a0per\u2009cent in that range. A bigger sample of lenses at redshift &gt;0.8 is needed to confirm the evolution of gamma with redshift and thereby constrain simulations and our corresponding understanding of the physics of galaxy evolution.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Finding strong lenses, especially at higher redshifts, remains a significant challenge. Currently several hundred examples of confirmed or likely galaxy\u2013galaxy strong lenses have been discovered (the Masterlens data base<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn2\" data-open=\"fn2\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">2</a></sup> Collett <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib15\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib15\" data-open=\"bib15\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>), with several hundred more awaiting spectroscopic or high-resolution follow-up. Modelling such as Collett (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib15\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib15\" data-open=\"bib15\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>) and Treu (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib74\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib74\" data-open=\"bib74\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>) predicts that several thousand lenses should be detectable in current surveys such as the Dark Energy Survey (DES; The DES Collaboration <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib72\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib72\" data-open=\"bib72\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2005</a>) and tens of thousands in next-generation surveys such as the Large Synoptic Survey Telescope (LSST; Ivezic et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib37\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib37\" data-open=\"bib37\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>) and Euclid (Amiaux et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib4\" data-open=\"bib4\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">In the past, entire surveys could be searched by eye, but the data sets are now of a scale that makes this impractical. Previous strategies for automating the lens search have included searching images for characteristic features such as arcs and rings (Lenzen, Schindler\u00a0&amp; Scherzer <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib48\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib48\" data-open=\"bib48\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2004</a>; Alard <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib3\" data-open=\"bib3\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>; Estrada et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib24\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib24\" data-open=\"bib24\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>; Seidel\u00a0&amp; Bartelmann <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib67\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib67\" data-open=\"bib67\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>; More et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib54\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib54\" data-open=\"bib54\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; Gavazzi et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib28\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib28\" data-open=\"bib28\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>), searching for red-near-blue sources (Bolton et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib8\" data-open=\"bib8\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>; Diehl et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib20\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib20\" data-open=\"bib20\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>), applying machine learning to survey catalogues (Agnello et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib2\" data-open=\"bib2\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>), and modelling sources as lenses and testing the quality of the residual for a match (Marshall et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib51\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib51\" data-open=\"bib51\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>; Chan et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib12\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib12\" data-open=\"bib12\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>). Citizen scientists have also been recruited, with 30\u2009000 volunteers helping to search the Canada-France-Hawaii Telescope Legacy Survey (CFHTLS) for strong lenses (Marshall et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib50\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib50\" data-open=\"bib50\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>; More et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib53\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib53\" data-open=\"bib53\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>). Some recent efforts have focused on machine learning techniques, in particular \u2018Deep Learning\u2019, involving the use of large artificial neural networks (ANNs). These techniques have already proved effective at finding lenses. Neural nets can effectively distinguish between simulated lenses and non-lenses (Avestruz et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib5\" data-open=\"bib5\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>; Hezaveh, Levasseur\u00a0&amp; Marshall <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib33\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib33\" data-open=\"bib33\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>; Jacobs et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib38\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib38\" data-open=\"bib38\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>; Lanusse et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib45\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib45\" data-open=\"bib45\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>). Applying the technique to surveys, Jacobs et al (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib38\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib38\" data-open=\"bib38\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>) used an ensemble of convolutional neural networks (CNNs) to find several hundred previously known lenses and 17 new candidates in CFHTLS in under an hour of astronomer review time, and Petrillo et al (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib60\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib60\" data-open=\"bib60\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>) used CNNs to identify 56 new lens candidates in the Kilo Degree Survey (KiDS).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">In DES, previous searches have relied heavily on the inspection of many thousands of candidates chosen from catalogue photometry (see Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5-6\"></span><a href=\"#sec5-6\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">5.6</a>). Collett\u2019s (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib15\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib15\" data-open=\"bib15\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>) simulation suggests that approximately 8\u00a0per\u2009cent of detectable lenses (\u223c110 lenses) should lie at redshifts &gt;0.8. It is these lenses that are the target of the search detailed in this work.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">In this paper, we describe a first search for high-redshift lenses in the DES using machine learning techniques. The paper is structured as follows. In Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec2\"></span><a href=\"#sec2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">2</a>, we provide some brief background on the machine learning technique employed in the search, namely ANNs. In Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3\"></span><a href=\"#sec3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">3</a>, we outline the methodology for constructing simulations to train the neural networks, building a catalogue of sources to search, and employing the trained networks on survey data. In Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4\"></span><a href=\"#sec4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">4</a>, we present the results of the search. In Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5\"></span><a href=\"#sec5\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">5</a>, we consider ways to evaluate the performance of the lens-finding method and improve future searches, and some prospects for follow-up science and further development of the technique, the summarize our conclusions in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec6\"></span><a href=\"#sec6\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">6</a>.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=130796738 id=\"130796738\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2>2 ARTIFICIAL NEURAL NETWORKS</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Here, we employ a machine learning technique to automatically find galaxy\u2013galaxy strong lenses in DES image data. Whilst traditional approaches to data problems rely on algorithms developed by subject-matter experts who define key features in the data and their relative contributions to the problem space, machine learning techniques extract features and their importance from data alone. See (Jordan\u00a0&amp; Mitchell <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib39\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib39\" data-open=\"bib39\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>) for an overview of the theory and applications of machine learning. ANNs are a machine learning technique first developed in the 1950s (Rosenblatt <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib64\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib64\" data-open=\"bib64\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1957</a>) and more heavily researched in the 1980s and 1990s (Fukushima <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib27\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib27\" data-open=\"bib27\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1980</a>) as non-trivial networks became computationally more tractable. ANNs are constructed to loosely mimic the structure of the brain, with a network of interconnected \u2018neurons\u2019, the strengths of the connection influencing how each neuron responds to a signal from its peers. Each artificial neuron takes an input vector; calculates the dot product with a vector of weights (i.e.\u00a0real numbers that weight the contribution of each input value); and passes the resulting scalar through a non-linear function such as a logistic function or hyperbolic tangent. Neurons are arranged in layers, with an input layer at one end, an arbitrary number of \u2018hidden layers\u2019 and an output layer interpreted appropriately to the problem domain, such as the probabilities a given input lies in one of N classes (see Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>). In theory, the connections between the neurons/layers can represent a highly non-linear decision boundary in many dimensions. The process of finding optimal values for the weights \u2013 the training \u2013 is data driven (see below).</p>                        <a id=\"130796740\" scrollto-destination=\"130796740\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig1\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 1.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/484/4/10.1093_mnras_stz272/1/m_stz272fig1.jpeg?Expires=1611465246&amp;Signature=aXFS0WOMCu~lzSfu2gjWp8LOQwhvgzlmYerrRbZ11OwexAonc3~SzQEAAjm3XyvSA-A~IDc05jgBfk4L3kY0UAS-J8OZ2tNMyxVUH8BhjIAOleXfQyuRSYhEWJQfEBOMBshstY8f4UpYJUDilYiN3cepCk3pL35DUqnKIzArYucwr4eQAX0fYjnguucbJfBTdNiMDh3eG3RPGBR9fFRD4ii81Ej0Bn1dsH5aAfxspGG~fWaxXfhaTinJngnSCtgSlIh0QvsyjEqQTL0HxRO9t5XZnfkU8hVkK92K40T8xtOBmsLPM7fBOn~1zmJ9Dp1C89eIbC1AAzCAsc43ZQdkqg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Overview of artificial networks. Top left: An artificial neuron. The element-wise weighted sum of a vector input is passed through a non-linear activation function (such as the logistic function, arctangent, or ReLU) to produce a scalar output. Top right: An example of a small fully-connected ANN, consisting of layers of artificial neurons. Blue: Input layer, equal in size to dimensionality of input data. Green: Hidden layers. Purple: Output layer; the outputs are interpreted according to the problem domain. Bottom: Prototypical convolutional neural network. Convolutional kernels are scanned across the input to build up so-called feature maps; pooling layers subsample the preceding layer to reduce the spatial extent. This process is repeated some number of times, then the resulting feature maps are passed to one or more fully-connected layers, followed by the output (yes/no) as the last layer.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz272fig1.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/130796740/stz272fig1.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz272fig1.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"130796740\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/484/4/10.1093_mnras_stz272/1/stz272fig1.jpeg?Expires=1611465246&Signature=VHtrfa-9YEf6jVLxjNNjltv4lRrnjzjfgjKnJNTby9gUpMo3ZJfCR33V-BZB67~X1Y-Q0bBPvIuP9k2qRJz9PbtwJm-yIGaKCWLxNT1Bi1xZ7lC1CLWc-UUzNSyTQ3Xv465ewtHajGhsYEaM8IkHLl-Mf~tkD~PUCok-nYtWDoC-5OBPf3bqkEuOHAl4U5IVpgAWst-V18S42dXgB3QaqrbzklSpZVNyzcAY07q0MbyUWT1P8F2iXk8~ojqjWI7SOByqfxnffIDYprdhlRBX-H4nQw8f2T1~3AKwOo9~kW-UBh-neVz-JuC11UXv2fW-Tko7~wqy0o6WyXb-p4F6Iw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=130796740&ar=5301418&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz272fig1.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Overview of artificial networks. <em>Top left</em>: An artificial neuron. The element-wise weighted sum of a vector input is passed through a non-linear activation function (such as the logistic function, arctangent, or ReLU) to produce a scalar output. <em>Top right</em>: An example of a small fully-connected ANN, consisting of layers of artificial neurons. Blue: Input layer, equal in size to dimensionality of input data. Green: Hidden layers. Purple: Output layer; the outputs are interpreted according to the problem domain. <em>Bottom</em>: Prototypical convolutional neural network. Convolutional kernels are scanned across the input to build up so-called feature maps; pooling layers subsample the preceding layer to reduce the spatial extent. This process is repeated some number of times, then the resulting feature maps are passed to one or more fully-connected layers, followed by the output (yes/no) as the last layer.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig1\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 1.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/484/4/10.1093_mnras_stz272/1/m_stz272fig1.jpeg?Expires=1611465246&amp;Signature=aXFS0WOMCu~lzSfu2gjWp8LOQwhvgzlmYerrRbZ11OwexAonc3~SzQEAAjm3XyvSA-A~IDc05jgBfk4L3kY0UAS-J8OZ2tNMyxVUH8BhjIAOleXfQyuRSYhEWJQfEBOMBshstY8f4UpYJUDilYiN3cepCk3pL35DUqnKIzArYucwr4eQAX0fYjnguucbJfBTdNiMDh3eG3RPGBR9fFRD4ii81Ej0Bn1dsH5aAfxspGG~fWaxXfhaTinJngnSCtgSlIh0QvsyjEqQTL0HxRO9t5XZnfkU8hVkK92K40T8xtOBmsLPM7fBOn~1zmJ9Dp1C89eIbC1AAzCAsc43ZQdkqg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Overview of artificial networks. Top left: An artificial neuron. The element-wise weighted sum of a vector input is passed through a non-linear activation function (such as the logistic function, arctangent, or ReLU) to produce a scalar output. Top right: An example of a small fully-connected ANN, consisting of layers of artificial neurons. Blue: Input layer, equal in size to dimensionality of input data. Green: Hidden layers. Purple: Output layer; the outputs are interpreted according to the problem domain. Bottom: Prototypical convolutional neural network. Convolutional kernels are scanned across the input to build up so-called feature maps; pooling layers subsample the preceding layer to reduce the spatial extent. This process is repeated some number of times, then the resulting feature maps are passed to one or more fully-connected layers, followed by the output (yes/no) as the last layer.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz272fig1.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/130796740/stz272fig1.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz272fig1.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"130796740\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/484/4/10.1093_mnras_stz272/1/stz272fig1.jpeg?Expires=1611465246&Signature=VHtrfa-9YEf6jVLxjNNjltv4lRrnjzjfgjKnJNTby9gUpMo3ZJfCR33V-BZB67~X1Y-Q0bBPvIuP9k2qRJz9PbtwJm-yIGaKCWLxNT1Bi1xZ7lC1CLWc-UUzNSyTQ3Xv465ewtHajGhsYEaM8IkHLl-Mf~tkD~PUCok-nYtWDoC-5OBPf3bqkEuOHAl4U5IVpgAWst-V18S42dXgB3QaqrbzklSpZVNyzcAY07q0MbyUWT1P8F2iXk8~ojqjWI7SOByqfxnffIDYprdhlRBX-H4nQw8f2T1~3AKwOo9~kW-UBh-neVz-JuC11UXv2fW-Tko7~wqy0o6WyXb-p4F6Iw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=130796740&ar=5301418&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz272fig1.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Overview of artificial networks. <em>Top left</em>: An artificial neuron. The element-wise weighted sum of a vector input is passed through a non-linear activation function (such as the logistic function, arctangent, or ReLU) to produce a scalar output. <em>Top right</em>: An example of a small fully-connected ANN, consisting of layers of artificial neurons. Blue: Input layer, equal in size to dimensionality of input data. Green: Hidden layers. Purple: Output layer; the outputs are interpreted according to the problem domain. <em>Bottom</em>: Prototypical convolutional neural network. Convolutional kernels are scanned across the input to build up so-called feature maps; pooling layers subsample the preceding layer to reduce the spatial extent. This process is repeated some number of times, then the resulting feature maps are passed to one or more fully-connected layers, followed by the output (yes/no) as the last layer.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">The combination of improved technique, widely-available GPU computing, and the availability of large, labelled data sets means that large ANNs with many layers (\u2018deep\u2019 ANNs) are now practical. This \u2018Deep Learning\u2019 resurgence has revolutionized several fields such as computer vision and speech recognition that were able to make breakthroughs in accuracy exceeding the performance of the best hand-engineered algorithms by large margins (Schmidhuber <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib66\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib66\" data-open=\"bib66\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>; Guo et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib30\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib30\" data-open=\"bib30\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">CNNs (LeCun et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib46\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib46\" data-open=\"bib46\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1989</a>) in particular have proven highly effective at discovering patterns in image data. Unlike a standard ANN, where each layer is fully connected to the previous layer, a convolutional layer connects only small groups of neighbouring neurons, and shares the weights between groups. This has the effect of vastly reducing the number of trainable weights whilst at the same time taking advantage of the fact that in visual data neighbouring inputs \u2013 i.e.\u00a0pixels \u2013 are highly correlated in meaningful ways. In effect, the network uses (usually square \u2013 e.g.\u00a05x5 pixels) \u2018convolutional kernels\u2019 that are convolved with the input image or outputs of a previous layer, and act as feature detectors. Outputs are then pooled, taking the mean or maximum value of groups of pixels, reducing the spatial extent of the data as the number of feature maps increases. At earlier layers, raw features such as edges and patches of colour are detected; at later layers, the network detects patterns in an increasingly abstract and high-level feature space. Thus, at early layers the network activates on lines and curves; at intermediate layers on combinations of these into semantically meaningful features; then at later layers, combining these semantic features into a representation of the input in a classification space.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">A CNN large enough to, for instance, distinguish between objects in hundreds of categories or decipher audio data into speech contains millions to hundreds of millions of parameters to be trained. This requires a large (i.e.\u00a0up to millions of examples) training set of labelled data with which to optimize the weights to achieve the desired output semantics. The full process for training a neural network, including the back-propagation algorithm, is detailed in LeCun et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib47\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib47\" data-open=\"bib47\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1998</a>). In brief, we construct a loss function <em>L</em> such that <em>L</em>\u00a0= 0 if the network classifies the training set perfectly, and increases as performance accuracy decreases. A typical loss function, and the one employed here, is a cross entropy loss function (Cao et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib10\" data-open=\"bib10\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>).<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn3\" data-open=\"fn3\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">3</a></sup></p><p class=\"chapter-para\">For each training example or batch of examples, and for each of the trainable weights <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$w$|</span><sub><em>i</em></sub> in the network, we calculate the gradient \u03b4<sub><em>i</em></sub>\u00a0= \u2202<em>L</em>/\u2202<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$w$|</span><sub><em>i</em></sub>. Then, following the standard gradient descent paradigm, we update the weights by <em>R</em>\u03b4<sub><em>i</em></sub> where <em>R</em> is a free parameter, the learning rate. In this way, with each iteration the weights become more optimal to producing a low <em>L</em> and thus more accurate classifications. Assuming a network of sufficient complexity to encode significant patterns and key features in the data, this performance will generalize to examples outside of the training set. If the dimensions of the network are not optimal, or the training set is too small, overfitting can occur where low loss is achieved on the training set but is not reflected in performance on examples not seen by the network during training. Typically, training examples are divided up into training, validation and test sets, where the training set is used to train the network and update the weights, validation is used to measure progress during training and assist in tuning parameters such as the learning rate, and the test set is reserved for a final estimate of network accuracy using labelled examples blinded from the network.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=130796745 id=\"130796745\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3>3 METHOD</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Constructing a neural network-based system for lens-finding requires the following steps. First, we assemble training sets. Due to the limited number of known galaxy\u2013galaxy lenses available, these consist of simulated strong lenses and non-lens systems (see Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3-2\"></span><a href=\"#sec3-2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">3.2</a>). We use the training set to iteratively train two CNNs using the <span class=\"small-caps\">Keras</span> Deep Learning framework (Chollet <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib14\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib14\" data-open=\"bib14\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>) on a GPU machine. We then take a catalogue of 1.1 million sources selected to match the simulations in <em>g</em> \u2212 <em>i</em> and <em>g</em> \u2212 <em>r</em> colour space and evaluate postage stamp images of each galaxy with the neural networks, producing a score in the interval (0, 1) for each image. We manually examine images with scores greater than a chosen threshold and grade them 0\u20133, where 0 = not a lens, 1 = possibly a lens, 2 = probably a lens, and 3 \u00a0=\u00a0definitely a lens.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=130796747 id=\"130796747\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-1>3.1 Choosing the target source population</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Our science goal for the lens search is to assemble a population of lenses with measurable Einstein radii at redshifts \u22730.8 in order to probe their total mass profiles in this redshift range. Examining the spectral energy distribution (SED) of a typical lensing galaxy, i.e.\u00a0a red, quiescent elliptical, we see that at redshift \u22480.8 the rest-frame UV drop-off is pushed almost entirely redward out of the DECam <em>g</em>-band filter. Thus in this redshift range we expect that a galaxy-galaxy lens with sufficient magnification to be detectable would exhibit bright source flux in the g-band but would lack a bright lens counterpart in the centre of the image. This morphological hint is something we hypothesize will be utilized by the CNNs (see discussion in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5\"></span><a href=\"#sec5\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">5</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">In this section we describe the method used to choose a subset of sources in the DES to search for lenses. We use catalogue values to make these cuts, then test postage stamp images of selected sources taken from DES Y3A1 coadd imaging. We restrict our search to a subset of sources in the survey catalogue for two reasons. Firstly, it reduces the amount of computational resources required, a significant consideration for a survey with around \u223c10TB of image data. Secondly, even a hypothetical, extremely accurate lens finder with a 0.1\u00a0per\u2009cent false positive rate would be expected to identify 300\u2009000 false positives across a survey of this size, a number 2-3 orders of magnitude greater than the number of lenses we expect to discover (see Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5-3\"></span><a href=\"#sec5-3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">5.3</a>). We therefore seek to increase the purity of the sample by restricting the search to sources we know are much more likely to be lenses than the average catalogued galaxy.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">In catalogue space, ellipticals at these redshifts are very red and the vast majority will lie at colours <em>g</em> \u2212 <em>i</em> &gt; 3 and <em>g</em> \u2212 <em>r</em> &gt; 2. This serves as a starting point for our search for likely candidates. However, the presence of a magnified lensed source, most commonly a compact, blue, star-forming galaxy, will shift the system in colour space to a degree difficult to predict from first principles given the range of source and lens colours and magnifications we expect to see. In order to constrain our catalogue search we use simulated lenses, the production of which is detailed below in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3-2\"></span><a href=\"#sec3-2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">3.2</a>. We find that for a population of 10\u2009000 simulated high-redshift elliptical galaxies with simulated lensed sources superimposed, the distribution of colours is as depicted in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig2\" data-open=\"fig2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>. We depict the colours of our simulations with and without the lensed source. As the simulated ellipticals are faint or undetectable in <em>g</em>, there are large errors in the measured <em>g</em>-band magnitudes; this scatter is visible in the figure, compared to the raw colours of our synthetic 10\u00a0Gyr SED. Unlensed spirals are possible false positives.</p>                        <a id=\"130796751\" scrollto-destination=\"130796751\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig2\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 2.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/484/4/10.1093_mnras_stz272/1/m_stz272fig2.jpeg?Expires=1611465246&amp;Signature=3UqmpflkdRYwsTT5sytZk00WqjdDBO8tLXnA4aVakVVT~omAwpBCtKZhyggxKfdvlHU7Y6YeHSEGQa7CgdPNiT5amXfrIEnM9x~P6D7sXdz5pFimeW4~xf6KCxfGe7RRyLatekXWnczynGCJwtxGOjDzweOx2lw5F9EnNDffNIFXfojYxed-uJgn4FKtu7OLLa3z6yAx3UmpuM~WOlTBdpk6ucgj8aqieELjAiIWfZlNHxaV6K6gPYweRMNU~XN3-4HJribqrnToXth6nbQhVZR6eRQjuQkMkEULM2kPjyRFws2eb9aUBcUP6Xcr4AkorJWaGXow6vixpIuf0-9KsQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"The colours (in g \u2212 i and g \u2212 r) of simulated lenses at redshifts &gt; 0.8, showing simulations without lensed source (blue/cyan) or with (green). As the simulated ellipticals are faint or undetectable in g by design, there are large errors in the measured g-band magnitudes; this diagonal scatter (i.e. along the g axis) is visible in the figure, compared to the raw colours of our LensPop synthetic 10\u00a0Gyr SED (redshifts 0.8\u20131.5 depicted in magenta). Simulated lenses with photometric g-band magnitude errors &lt;0.2 are depicted in dark blue, the rest in cyan. We depict a set of red through blue pegase.2 (Fioc\u00a0&amp; Rocca-Volmerange 1999) template tracks, with progressively increasing amounts of recent star formation to illustrate where normal z&lt;1.5 unlensed galaxies are expected to lie. The red dashed line is the PEGASE 10\u00a0Gyr simple stellar population model (similar to our synthetic SED); the arrows point out kinks in the colour track at redshifts 0.4 and 1. A random selection of DES catalogue sources is depicted as red points, indicating where the denser parts of the catalogue lie; our colour cuts are depicted as black boxes.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz272fig2.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/130796751/stz272fig2.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz272fig2.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"130796751\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/484/4/10.1093_mnras_stz272/1/stz272fig2.jpeg?Expires=1611465246&Signature=ZVlmIrWIdJ4D2MdCnBCxwbhDaW9E76Tb4WE18Ad4NjJpELJ4hs7g7j9f4DqssTL2Wu0A6fUJOW2PS6OrwUcOPwb3PphkKz2h5SeGlafbfrROOR5bTuUsyfpb~askprrhncMQo8YHHDwZMYjkkQFUpyf9GzBNvMmx-plPRcLbrD3tSYF0cOGrpJJwEBtc~lPAhh~8fkcz3NQDcdzVItFublQroFeXb-fgZcrBnlR4rExbtQZdtu6p9kP64JgVPZdaOMO98K-Pqobg66ryGnIL~UiVtrDTeA9I-K4noWOlih-SfW7PEz4jTZA9SZ8u3K1rTQlaO28Zuf8GhbPVxiPcWA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=130796751&ar=5301418&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz272fig2.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">The colours (in <em>g</em> \u2212 <em>i</em> and <em>g</em> \u2212 <em>r</em>) of simulated lenses at redshifts &gt; 0.8, showing simulations without lensed source (blue/cyan) or with (green). As the simulated ellipticals are faint or undetectable in g by design, there are large errors in the measured <em>g</em>-band magnitudes; this diagonal scatter (i.e. along the g axis) is visible in the figure, compared to the raw colours of our <span class=\"small-caps\">LensPop</span> synthetic 10\u00a0Gyr SED (redshifts 0.8\u20131.5 depicted in magenta). Simulated lenses with photometric g-band magnitude errors &lt;0.2 are depicted in dark blue, the rest in cyan. We depict a set of red through blue <span class=\"small-caps\">pegase</span>.2 (Fioc\u00a0&amp; Rocca-Volmerange <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib25\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib25\" data-open=\"bib25\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1999</a>) template tracks, with progressively increasing amounts of recent star formation to illustrate where normal z&lt;1.5 unlensed galaxies are expected to lie. The red dashed line is the PEGASE 10\u00a0Gyr simple stellar population model (similar to our synthetic SED); the arrows point out kinks in the colour track at redshifts 0.4 and 1. A random selection of DES catalogue sources is depicted as red points, indicating where the denser parts of the catalogue lie; our colour cuts are depicted as black boxes.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">The addition of a lensed source shifts the simulated systems towards the blue end of the spectrum by up to three magnitudes. The colours used are the intrinsic colours of the simulated lens systems, with shot noise but without sky or any contaminants such as nearby objects. Looking at the area of colour space where the majority of simulated lenses lie, we build a catalogue as follows: We choose sources with colours 2 &lt; <em>g</em> \u2212 <em>i</em> &lt; 5, 0.6 &lt; <em>g</em> \u2212 <em>r</em> &lt; 3, allowing for a large errors in measured <em>g</em>-band magnitudes for faint sources. In order to test the diminishing returns predicted by the simulations outside this region, we supplement the catalogue with sources where 1.8 &lt; <em>g</em> \u2212 <em>i</em> &lt; 2, 0.8 &lt; <em>g</em> \u2212 <em>r</em> &lt; 1.2, as depicted in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig3\" data-open=\"fig3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a>. We also restrict ourselves to sources where <em>r</em><sub>mag</sub> &gt; 19, <em>g</em><sub>mag</sub> &gt; 20, <em>i</em><sub>mag</sub> &gt; 18.2 again following the distribution of simulated lens luminosities. This represents less than 0.5\u00a0per\u2009cent of the total survey catalogue. As we move bluer than this region of colour space, the number of sources in the DES catalogue to examine increases rapidly, and the number of simulated lenses decreases just as sharply. We expect rapidly diminishing returns and so limit our search to this region, which includes 93.4\u00a0per\u2009cent of the simulated lenses. We discuss this further in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5-2\"></span><a href=\"#sec5-2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">5.2</a>.</p>                        <a id=\"130796753\" scrollto-destination=\"130796753\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig3\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 3.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/484/4/10.1093_mnras_stz272/1/m_stz272fig3.jpeg?Expires=1611465246&amp;Signature=bCCu~~Wt-trbBQu3AQWtsQvogWshkj8Fn0Iqyf4lcP6pZqQDze6GPNChpNUZvlEYxWk4bweCpSUnBdwrIMaMgqIdzWukUD8wTR6ht2uYGsfaU5VBjiLRP7469vUQ~YzTHVEF3~d6PIJy7L2Tpq2HghCI126Ry26n~7XBEDiS5fYd049XRI7n3M7vX96eOpdsZheftIgl5oxQtAld3Rc4v8xNkrQR4Nr-Gc69DbqSna6KQ4UXr0-D0F2tRZpXsy3F1Wx3wL~hsSAz07D2HhJ2o87KNI3mO0tCi~BOS556m30r0y4jXATDIOgKhU6aLOYVGiGkF-CQK7inPmJ4bXs6Lg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Catalogue sources (green) and new lens candidates (blue). We choose sources from the catalogue that are within the boxes depicted, where 2 &lt; <em>g</em> \u2212 <em>i</em> &lt; 5, 0.6 &lt; <em>g</em> \u2212 <em>r</em> &lt; 3, and where 1.8 &lt; <em>g</em> \u2212 <em>i</em> &lt; 2, 0.8 &lt; <em>g</em> \u2212 <em>r</em> &lt; 1.2.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig3\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 3.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/484/4/10.1093_mnras_stz272/1/m_stz272fig3.jpeg?Expires=1611465246&amp;Signature=bCCu~~Wt-trbBQu3AQWtsQvogWshkj8Fn0Iqyf4lcP6pZqQDze6GPNChpNUZvlEYxWk4bweCpSUnBdwrIMaMgqIdzWukUD8wTR6ht2uYGsfaU5VBjiLRP7469vUQ~YzTHVEF3~d6PIJy7L2Tpq2HghCI126Ry26n~7XBEDiS5fYd049XRI7n3M7vX96eOpdsZheftIgl5oxQtAld3Rc4v8xNkrQR4Nr-Gc69DbqSna6KQ4UXr0-D0F2tRZpXsy3F1Wx3wL~hsSAz07D2HhJ2o87KNI3mO0tCi~BOS556m30r0y4jXATDIOgKhU6aLOYVGiGkF-CQK7inPmJ4bXs6Lg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Catalogue sources (green) and new lens candidates (blue). Green contours indicated where simulated strong lenses lie. The dashed lines show a best fit colour\u2013colour relation for the simulated lenses, with 3\u03c3 lines shown. Green contours indicated where simulated strong lenses lie. The dashed lines show a best fit colour\u2013colour relation for the simulated lenses, with 3\u03c3 lines shown. We choose sources from the catalogue that are within the boxes depicted, where 2 &lt; <em>g</em> \u2212 <em>i</em> &lt; 5, 0.6 &lt; <em>g</em> \u2212 <em>r</em> &lt; 3, and where 1.8 &lt; <em>g</em> \u2212 <em>i</em> &lt; 2, 0.8 &lt; <em>g</em> \u2212 <em>r</em> &lt; 1.2.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">We discard sources with undefined magnitude errors or flux errors in <em>gri</em> bands, or where more than 400 pixels are masked out in the 100 \u00d7 100 postage stamps. We assemble a catalogue to search of 831\u00a0056 and 230\u00a0812 in the supplementary catalogue, for a total of 1061\u00a0868 sources selected from the complete DES catalogue.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=130796755 id=\"130796755\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-2>3.2 Generating simulations</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">In order to optimise a neural network with millions of trainable parameters (\u2018weights\u2019) we require a training set of sufficient size. State-of-the-art neural networks used in general computer vision applications require of order 10<sup>6</sup> training examples for robust training (e.g. Krizhevsky, Sutskever\u00a0&amp; Hinton <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib43\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib43\" data-open=\"bib43\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>). Given that the number of discovered lenses across all surveys and instruments is in the hundreds, we must simulate lenses in order to create a training set of sufficient size. We use a modified version of the <span class=\"small-caps\">LensPop</span> code described in Collett (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib15\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib15\" data-open=\"bib15\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>) for this purpose.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\"><span class=\"small-caps\">LensPop</span> generates a population of synthetic galaxies with a singular isothermal ellipsoid (SIE) mass profile and redshifts, masses and ellipticities drawn from realistic distributions following the <span class=\"small-caps\">LensPop</span> methodology (Collett <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib15\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib15\" data-open=\"bib15\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>). Deflector masses are drawn from the velocity dispersion function of SDSS (Choi, Park\u00a0&amp; Vogeley <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib13\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib13\" data-open=\"bib13\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>) without redshift dependence and a constant comoving density out to redshift 2. Lens colours assume a 10 Gyr-old quiescent SED. Sources are elliptical exponential discs with redshifts sizes and colours drawn from the COSMOS sample (Ilbert et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib36\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib36\" data-open=\"bib36\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>). Lens light is added to the resulting image using the Fundamental Plane relation (Hyde\u00a0&amp; Bernardi <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib35\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib35\" data-open=\"bib35\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>) assuming a de Vaucolours profile and the SED of an old passive galaxy. We shift the brightness profile of the sources by one magnitude brighter in all bands to create a larger sample of detectable lenses. This makes the process more efficient in terms of detectable lenses generated per second; generating an unrealistically rich sample of bright, detectable lenses is not problematic when our goal is simply to train our CNN and not constrain lensing statistics in the real universe.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The <span class=\"small-caps\">LensPop</span> code generates our synthetic population of lenses and sources. The simulations are then pruned as follows. First, lenses with redshifts &gt;2 and &lt;0.8 are discarded. Lens images are then simulated using <span class=\"small-caps\">gravlens</span> (Keeton <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib41\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib41\" data-open=\"bib41\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2001</a>) raytracing code. Images in <em>g, r</em>, and <em>i</em> bands are produced with seeing drawn from the DES Year 1 science verification data with a floor of 0.9\u00a0arcsec in all bands; typical seeing of 1.1\u20131.2 arcsec.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Simulated shot noise is added. Lenses with signal-to-noise ratio &lt; 3, Einstein radii &lt; twice seeing and magnifications less than 3 are discarded, as they are unlikely to be detectable in DES imaging. We generate two sets of images, as FITS files 100 pixels (30\u00a0arcsec) on a side, the first with both the flux from the lensed source \u2013 positive examples (\u2018a strong lens\u2019) and secondly, without \u2013 negative examples (\u2018no lensing depicted\u2019). These simulated lenses are combined with randomly chosen tiles from the DES imaging to add sky and read noise, stars, realistic background and foreground objects, artefacts, and so on. We assembled a training set of 250\u2009000 images as depicted in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig4\" data-open=\"fig4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a>. A histogram of the redshifts of the simulations is depicted in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig5\" data-open=\"fig5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">5</a>.</p>                        <a id=\"130796760\" scrollto-destination=\"130796760\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig4\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 4.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/484/4/10.1093_mnras_stz272/1/m_stz272fig4.jpeg?Expires=1611465247&amp;Signature=Pc6gn~zK9-mfqQVZELNuP3iaSO0OS2D~HpRlMqvPSZNG0SDbq0X5xQr0zFy743yAwUxkY2MuTFMLPyaeR1q~o3CNXKBDytXzqwVjrpzFsCAoHiMmRZungnooE~cRm7NXGRB6WPEIZtZapKswJHQxBi6tjUU1--s2QpKnkWWaq9HFoahxk10fxJamZSEq-5RCgb97r4VcG~pFwbbnIL-ux8dD7veeo~OhoVOloXLn~cvjxZoDKP01VzLHRp9zNExyAsn4B~iTLPW3it5Q-ySnx3sdf7bMMU1B38ZfOfjNtjMP0VSvTY0OPGo8KlooWxfntyW6g-YZeD2inwMlGWkcPw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Simulated lenses for the training set (RGB images from g, r, i bands). Right: Without lensed source (negative examples).</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig4\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 4.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/484/4/10.1093_mnras_stz272/1/m_stz272fig4.jpeg?Expires=1611465247&amp;Signature=Pc6gn~zK9-mfqQVZELNuP3iaSO0OS2D~HpRlMqvPSZNG0SDbq0X5xQr0zFy743yAwUxkY2MuTFMLPyaeR1q~o3CNXKBDytXzqwVjrpzFsCAoHiMmRZungnooE~cRm7NXGRB6WPEIZtZapKswJHQxBi6tjUU1--s2QpKnkWWaq9HFoahxk10fxJamZSEq-5RCgb97r4VcG~pFwbbnIL-ux8dD7veeo~OhoVOloXLn~cvjxZoDKP01VzLHRp9zNExyAsn4B~iTLPW3it5Q-ySnx3sdf7bMMU1B38ZfOfjNtjMP0VSvTY0OPGo8KlooWxfntyW6g-YZeD2inwMlGWkcPw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Simulated lenses for the training set (RGB images from g, r, i bands). Right: Without lensed source (negative examples).</p></div></div>                        <a id=\"130796761\" scrollto-destination=\"130796761\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig5\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 5.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/484/4/10.1093_mnras_stz272/1/m_stz272fig5.jpeg?Expires=1611465247&amp;Signature=eXNDIHWf~evNb6I4PHemt2afssXm~CR2p0RDYj0LI70KwrrjiEDj8v93sMVNPZR-~Pk~kJ0Kzc7FX~c9ZenjKIqAKnYA15MEpVqzvwTJfY4HcIyvEFaEqqE70RClQcvT8TIreif9xx85zxxOb09DC0mz-t1QEsalC5rH0axMzcmzeq5XCj53~ikQns2KDR9nsDtaHOXtYBLtvymXm2SBZHcgrYVwMvFMkY3KMmohQVWvzZffGXnSb6rvRPkCS8IZgnf~46CzpvHtwb6cj6FVClPvyg-i7~4fFeDqOGJ1BWgKTf8i3FX00TQelUdotbB~NTXnGnAWW6fbHwsVbglrGg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Redshift distribution of lens galaxies and lensed sources for simulations used in training the networks. This includes only lenses at redshift &gt;0.8 and the associated sources.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz272fig5.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/130796761/stz272fig5.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz272fig5.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"130796761\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/484/4/10.1093_mnras_stz272/1/stz272fig5.jpeg?Expires=1611465247&Signature=E6L7OI2Qvbv-cfeUp51H7zoGcgGgDcqDC2FwxQVrndpgd9XGhIDGRc9P6sjepqRdHhD~Mvade7EAje5HLzm7mK9f--m8JBfxVMF2JETIC1klMSs28hlGXtnkOs1IMp5s59bnK1gzlfatTQeO8oK6XLC9KAFRGSnk-F-kfanQF7doqTCIph4EKkp2RiDE7mb5zmVxCbsgC3UX-3LHJUngsUXxRzo6iOst02tHG3Hz2HK4aDgSF15IbMj7NcyR0tTdal0HGiNBk-LcRMLZB~8EQsifDL7lUbZsw-gcxCGuLd7xd3EvGsx~ERR5kTd3qtetO8pYL-OYgMvadLiIy0U62Q__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=130796761&ar=5301418&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz272fig5.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Redshift distribution of lens galaxies and lensed sources for simulations used in training the networks. This includes only lenses at redshift &gt;0.8 and the associated sources.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig5\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 5.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/484/4/10.1093_mnras_stz272/1/m_stz272fig5.jpeg?Expires=1611465247&amp;Signature=eXNDIHWf~evNb6I4PHemt2afssXm~CR2p0RDYj0LI70KwrrjiEDj8v93sMVNPZR-~Pk~kJ0Kzc7FX~c9ZenjKIqAKnYA15MEpVqzvwTJfY4HcIyvEFaEqqE70RClQcvT8TIreif9xx85zxxOb09DC0mz-t1QEsalC5rH0axMzcmzeq5XCj53~ikQns2KDR9nsDtaHOXtYBLtvymXm2SBZHcgrYVwMvFMkY3KMmohQVWvzZffGXnSb6rvRPkCS8IZgnf~46CzpvHtwb6cj6FVClPvyg-i7~4fFeDqOGJ1BWgKTf8i3FX00TQelUdotbB~NTXnGnAWW6fbHwsVbglrGg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Redshift distribution of lens galaxies and lensed sources for simulations used in training the networks. This includes only lenses at redshift &gt;0.8 and the associated sources.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz272fig5.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/130796761/stz272fig5.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz272fig5.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"130796761\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/484/4/10.1093_mnras_stz272/1/stz272fig5.jpeg?Expires=1611465247&Signature=E6L7OI2Qvbv-cfeUp51H7zoGcgGgDcqDC2FwxQVrndpgd9XGhIDGRc9P6sjepqRdHhD~Mvade7EAje5HLzm7mK9f--m8JBfxVMF2JETIC1klMSs28hlGXtnkOs1IMp5s59bnK1gzlfatTQeO8oK6XLC9KAFRGSnk-F-kfanQF7doqTCIph4EKkp2RiDE7mb5zmVxCbsgC3UX-3LHJUngsUXxRzo6iOst02tHG3Hz2HK4aDgSF15IbMj7NcyR0tTdal0HGiNBk-LcRMLZB~8EQsifDL7lUbZsw-gcxCGuLd7xd3EvGsx~ERR5kTd3qtetO8pYL-OYgMvadLiIy0U62Q__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=130796761&ar=5301418&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz272fig5.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Redshift distribution of lens galaxies and lensed sources for simulations used in training the networks. This includes only lenses at redshift &gt;0.8 and the associated sources.</p></div></div>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=130796762 id=\"130796762\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-3>3.3 Training CNNs</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The CNNs were architected with four convolutional layers with kernel sizes 11, 5, 3, and 3, respectively, and one fully connected layer of 1024 neurons. The non-linearity function is the rectified linear unit (ReLU)<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn4\" data-open=\"fn4\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">4</a></sup>; a dropout (see Hinton et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib34\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib34\" data-open=\"bib34\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>) of 0.25 is added after the last convolutional layer, and 0.5 between fully connected layers. This network architecture is similar to industry standard network architectures such as AlexNet (Krizhevsky et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib43\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib43\" data-open=\"bib43\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>), but much simpler than the most complex networks used for computer vision [e.g.\u00a0ResNet (He et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib32\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib32\" data-open=\"bib32\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>), up to 1000 layers]. The network contains a total of 8833\u00a0794 trainable weights. The number of layers and their dimensions are free parameters, and an optimal architecture is still a matter of some guesswork. This network architecture was chosen based on previous experience (Jacobs et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib38\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib38\" data-open=\"bib38\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>) and was deemed fit for purpose based on the high accuracy realized during the training process. A deeper network could potentially result in higher training accuracy; however, the practical limitation appears to be the translation from simulations to real sources (see\u00a0Section <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5-4\"></span><a href=\"#sec5-4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">5.4</a>). A similar network to the one presented here was used by the authors to enter the Bologna Lens Finding Challenge (Metcalf et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib52\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib52\" data-open=\"bib52\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>) and placed third in the detection of simulated lenses in multiband imaging.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The networks were implemented, trained, and run using code employing the <span class=\"small-caps\">Keras</span> deep learning library and Theano numerical library (Team et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib71\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib71\" data-open=\"bib71\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>). Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig6\" data-open=\"fig6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">6</a> depicts the network architecture; the description of the <span class=\"small-caps\">Keras</span> model is also included in the Appendix.</p>                        <a id=\"130796765\" scrollto-destination=\"130796765\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig6\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 6.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img
