convolutional layers with kernel sizes 11, 5, 3, and 3, and two fully-connected layers of 1024 neurons each.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig6\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 6.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/484/4/10.1093_mnras_stz272/1/m_stz272fig6.jpeg?Expires=1611465247&amp;Signature=EZGJ0hki1liNVZAwR-qj239ELO0V0O~fIk48Xg4VV-ABZwPUJGqjLYRBUOz0gwYvCSstM0PImMQAv9v2scq25veqrqzVCpHwvN1yCqPBtfEFJO-Vu0rP7cTDktpW7GmSZ6GcU8So~aZAuUE6Wt7U5xOaqR-NHHTrJoxRJe0pPAEJ3DW6OJ4pYvnpjx-Zn0YRNSPw1qD6~FwEJBIL4OUXByiBPPRLknrOf0XqNaGBCWcKsXxtFGy4lnm-z8F1qIAwL8TyazHB7e4s2THFiFTcPBMK0pkZxQQRMQziP9dB3gtpgpYspgpYwNXuXJ~LJBQfhLVljhTOcfu6puD9h7Nd7Q__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Architecture of neural networks used: four convolutional layers with kernel sizes 11, 5, 3, and 3, and two fully-connected layers of 1024 neurons each.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz272fig6.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/130796765/stz272fig6.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz272fig6.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"130796765\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/484/4/10.1093_mnras_stz272/1/stz272fig6.jpeg?Expires=1611465247&Signature=hhWP0FGzH2vzyFQRXp1Hr550SbSFWEEutY5UXuGfdyXYqj9NclKcTjJtPYD~zneY6j66w~RwPWDf~5G1krNOs7jFsEjdQiXqAIyDxSPwtG8W~DV1tGTmS2jYghAPsp5FvqNOJS1z3ptOXVkG8B9nx0BSBwEggrEfJQVyN~vIu6Pqs6pHPTUQveCPdshjTbl4LAsHolaRw3ZCu9W9ntYHyblm9F-ztCL0BPoYTLSXsXCab4feHKByjB7qLfhJXHCf-0jo5ShtH6-2Qv5W6W4Q7mR53ClLS44QLHd950a4uEOv-0FBd-3ZKjGN0-HnjIe3TfNRo-qccXUWOwaI3kJtEQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=130796765&ar=5301418&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz272fig6.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Architecture of neural networks used: four convolutional layers with kernel sizes 11, 5, 3, and 3, and two fully-connected layers of 1024 neurons each.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">In total, 20 CNNs with these dimensions are trained, with differences as outlined below. We create two training sets, as summarized in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>. Training set 1 consists of 125\u2009000 simulated lenses and the same number of non-lensing elliptical galaxies. Training set 2 consists of 80\u2009000 simulated lenses and 80\u2009000 postage stamps of sources chosen at random from our search catalogue (Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4-2\"></span><a href=\"#sec4-2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">4.2</a> as negative examples). With the first training set, we ensure the network learns to reject simulations that do not exhibit detectable strong lensing, forcing it to learn from the morphology of lensing and not merely a characteristic of our simulations that inadvertently distinguishes the simulations from real galaxies. With the second training set, the networks will learn that objects we have not simulated \u2013 spirals, mergers, stars, and so on \u2013 are to be considered non-lenses. Since we expect only of order one lens in 10<sup>4</sup> sources, this negative training set may be \u2018contaminated\u2019 by a few actual lenses, but this will not have a discernible impact on training since the contribution of each training example to the weight updates is equal.</p>                        <a id=\"130796767\" scrollto-destination=\"130796767\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"tbl1\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl1\" data-id=\"tbl1\"><span class=\"label\">Table 1.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Training sets used to train neural networks.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>Training set<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Positive\u00a0examples<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Negative\u00a0examples<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Size<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>TS1\u00a0</td><td>Simulations\u00a0</td><td>Simulations\u00a0</td><td>250\u00a0000\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>TS2\u00a0</td><td>Simulations\u00a0</td><td>Real galaxies\u00a0</td><td>160\u00a0000\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-modal\"><table><thead><tr><th>Training set<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Positive\u00a0examples<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Negative\u00a0examples<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Size<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>TS1\u00a0</td><td>Simulations\u00a0</td><td>Simulations\u00a0</td><td>250\u00a0000\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>TS2\u00a0</td><td>Simulations\u00a0</td><td>Real galaxies\u00a0</td><td>160\u00a0000\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/130796767\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><div class=\"table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl1\" data-id=\"tbl1\"><span class=\"label\">Table 1.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Training sets used to train neural networks.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>Training set<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Positive\u00a0examples<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Negative\u00a0examples<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Size<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>TS1\u00a0</td><td>Simulations\u00a0</td><td>Simulations\u00a0</td><td>250\u00a0000\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>TS2\u00a0</td><td>Simulations\u00a0</td><td>Real galaxies\u00a0</td><td>160\u00a0000\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-modal\"><table><thead><tr><th>Training set<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Positive\u00a0examples<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Negative\u00a0examples<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Size<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>TS1\u00a0</td><td>Simulations\u00a0</td><td>Simulations\u00a0</td><td>250\u00a0000\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>TS2\u00a0</td><td>Simulations\u00a0</td><td>Real galaxies\u00a0</td><td>160\u00a0000\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/130796767\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">The use of two training sets with different non-lens images, as opposed to a single larger training set combining both, has the advantage that we can tune the weighting given to the contribution of the two training sets when assembling a candidate set by choosing different score thresholds for the two networks. This gives more fine-grained control in exploring the trade-off between purity and completeness and tuning the size of the candidate set to examine.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">For each of these two training sets, we divide each into 10 equally sized subsets (folds). For each fold, we train a network reserving that fold of the data as a validation set \u2013 not used for training, but used to measure training progress \u2013 and the remainder as the training examples. We thus obtain 10 networks trained on different subsets of the training examples to hand. This process is known as <em>k</em>-fold cross-validation (see Refaeilzadeh, Tang\u00a0&amp; Liu <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib62\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib62\" data-open=\"bib62\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a> for a detailed description). There is some stochasticity in the training process; the initial weights are randomized, the order in which the training set is fed to the network is also random, and by using slightly different training sets, each network thus trained will score candidates slightly differently. Using an ensemble allows us to smooth out the effects of outlier scores; we use the mean score from the 10 trained networks in selecting candidates. More than 10 networks per ensemble are unlikely to add additional information, but require GPU time to train. It has been shown (Hansen\u00a0&amp; Salamon <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib31\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib31\" data-open=\"bib31\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1990</a>; Krogh\u00a0&amp; Vedelsby <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib44\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib44\" data-open=\"bib44\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1995</a>) that using an ensemble of neural networks in this way can provide a significant boost to the accuracy of the system, e.g.\u00a0a 2\u00a0per\u2009cent increase in classification accuracy over the best performing network by an ensemble (Ju, Bibaut\u00a0&amp; van der Laan <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib40\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib40\" data-open=\"bib40\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>) \u2013 particularly, if the networks are trained with different training data (Giacinto\u00a0&amp; Roli <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib29\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib29\" data-open=\"bib29\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2001</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The networks are trained on FITS data in three bands (<em>g, r, i</em>), passed to the networks as 32-bit floating point values. The FITS data, which is background-subtracted, is further normalized so that across the training set, the mean value is zero and 99.7\u00a0per\u2009cent of the values lie between \u22122.5 and 2.5.<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn5\" data-open=\"fn5\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">5</a></sup> This is shown to optimize convergence by the training algorithm (LeCun et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib47\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib47\" data-open=\"bib47\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1998</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We train the networks until further iterations no longer decrease the loss value on the validation set. At each epoch (iteration through the training set), we test the accuracy of the network on the training and validation sets, and calculate the loss for each. We halt training when the loss on the validation set has decreased by less than a parameter \u03b5\u00a0= 0.0001 for six epochs. Further training beyond this point is likely to lead to overfitting to the training set.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=130796772 id=\"130796772\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-4>3.4 Scoring and sorting candidate sources</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Our target data set for the lens search is DES (Diehl et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib18\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib18\" data-open=\"bib18\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>; Flaugher et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib26\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib26\" data-open=\"bib26\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>; Diehl et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib19\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib19\" data-open=\"bib19\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>) Year 3 coadd images (Abbott et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib1\" data-open=\"bib1\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>; Morganson et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib55\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib55\" data-open=\"bib55\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>). This imaging consists of 10\u2009346 tiles over 5000 deg<sup>2</sup> of sky. The number of epochs is \u223c4\u20136 per coadd object per band, with a limiting magnitude in <em>r</em> of 24.9 and a pixel scale of 0.263\u00a0arcsec\u00a0pixel<sup>\u22121</sup>. The mean seeing is 1.06\u00a0arcsec in <em>g</em> (Diehl et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib21\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib21\" data-open=\"bib21\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>). We generate postage stamps in <em>g, r, i</em> and bands of dimensions 100x100 pixels for each of the million sources in our target catalogue. Each of the postage stamps is scored using the pre-trained CNNs to produce two scores in the interval (0, 1) corresponding to the two different training sets. We then examine the distribution of scores, and choose thresholds for each score to produce a subset of our catalogue for visual examination by human experts. We choose the threshold such that the candidate set is of a size that can be examined in a few hours, i.e.\u00a0a few thousand images. RGB images of each source are examined by eye (by authors CJ, KG, and TC) and graded using software, LensRater, developed for this purpose.<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn6\" data-open=\"fn6\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">6</a></sup> We rate the candidates as (0) unlikely to contain a lens: (1) possibly containing a lens, (2) probably containing a lens, and (3) almost certainly containing a lens. We then take the mean grade and assemble our final candidate catalogue from those graded 2 and above. In this paper, we define false positives as any candidates that we judge to be below grade 1. We then estimate the completeness of our sample of lens candidates.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=130796774 id=\"130796774\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-5>3.5 Estimating photometric redshifts</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The objects we discover in our search are lens candidates. In the absence of spectroscopic follow-up, we cannot know how many of them are genuine strong lenses, and of those that are, how many are in our target redshift range. In order to make a first-order approximation regarding the second question, we calculate photometric redshifts of the lens galaxies. We use the Bayesian Photometric Redshifts (<span class=\"small-caps\">bpz</span>) photo-<em>z</em> package.<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn7\" data-open=\"fn7\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">7</a></sup> As inputs to the photo-<em>z</em> code we use colours measured from the DES Y3 coadd images in <em>griz</em> with apertures fit manually to the galaxies (excluding blue source flux), with mag errors taken from the DES catalogue. We quote the best fit and 2\u03c3 uncertainties output by <span class=\"small-caps\">bpz</span>.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=130796776 id=\"130796776\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-6>3.6 Estimating the completeness of the sample</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Our workflow involves the evaluation of machine-selected candidates by human astronomers for follow-up. The optimal sample would therefore include all sources that a human astronomer would grade as probable or definite lenses, and not those that would be graded otherwise, whether or not they are, in reality, strong lenses. The completeness of our sample, as a measure of what can realistically be detected in the imaging we are searching, is a function of what an astronomer can discern with confidence from a composite RGB image used for evaluation.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Collett (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib15\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib15\" data-open=\"bib15\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>) used simulations to estimate the number of strong lenses discoverable in DES coadd imaging. Simulating the survey sky, using detectability criteria of signal-to-noise ratio in <em>g</em> greater than 20, magnification greater than 3, and an Einstein radius greater than the seeing (\u223c1\u00a0arcsec), Collett predicts \u223c1300 lenses should be discoverable by inspection of the images. These detectable lenses had a mean lens redshift of 0.42; 8\u00a0per\u2009cent (\u223c110) were at redshift 0.8\u20132.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">How many of these theoretically detectable lenses would actually be selected as good candidates by a human astronomer following our lens-finding pipeline is a testable question. To better understand this threshold, we collect one further piece of data. We assembled a set of 5000 postage stamps containing 2500 real galaxies, 1000 simulated lenses, 1000 simulated ellipticals, and 500 simulated ellipticals with unlensed blue sources nearby (\u2018phonies\u2019) and presented these, blinded, to authors TC and KG to evaluate. We then examine the number of simulated high-redshift lenses graded highly by the inspectors. Measuring the fraction of simulated lenses that were rated highly assists us in making an estimate of the true number of lenses we can expect to find in the survey using our automated pipeline. Of high-redshift simulated lenses examined, 51\u00a0per\u2009cent were given grade 0, indicating that estimates of detectability are highly dependent on image quality and grading methodology, and can easily be overestimated. We discuss this further in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5-3\"></span><a href=\"#sec5-3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">5.3</a>.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=130796780 id=\"130796780\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4>4 RESULTS</h2>\r\n                    <h3 scrollto-destination=130796781 id=\"130796781\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-1>4.1 Training neural networks</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Two ensembles of neural networks were trained as described in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3-3\"></span><a href=\"#sec3-3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">3.3</a>. For the first ensemble, trained on simulated lenses with and without lensed sources, the training converged after 30\u00a0\u00b1\u00a01 epochs in each case. The accuracy (the fraction of a sample classified correctly: true positives+true negatives divided by number of items tested) on the respective validation sets of the 10 networks in the ensemble was <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$98.6 \\pm 0.1{{\\ \\rm per\\ cent}}$|\u2060</span>. The training progress for a single network is depicted in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig7\" data-open=\"fig7\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">7</a>; after a single epoch, the training accuracy was 87\u00a0per\u2009cent, converging slowly on the final value. On the second training set, composed of simulated lenses and random sources from the catalogue, training converged in fewer epochs, 20\u00a0\u00b1\u00a02, with a validation accuracy of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$99.4 \\pm 0.1{{\\ \\rm per\\ cent}}$|\u2060</span>.</p>                        <a id=\"130796783\" scrollto-destination=\"130796783\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig7\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 7.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/484/4/10.1093_mnras_stz272/1/m_stz272fig7.jpeg?Expires=1611465247&amp;Signature=lMXc7Zye0Bs8~bMVFVh5fD4vSHGh~N~nZotfSytYef6G-LGnFmB6UCeB2NlhUDcD2IkJbwryxcS~mXjMT61Ppk-dBQEfJpaHA2KS3aAxwzUYh3ggk2RQx5f8PiPe7IncaNOoZpVnBKBbIS6DvP-PNMsv6dsyMxH93MSlNF8szEWpb9a7PUnbpgiSDwrJrsVdJj9HkWQgr6m9wGFOF-wSwAzdFV1CyPzefJoyQ0NlteH2y53USs87SAaYv9727Ym~J-hSFm0zD3WiKk1PE9x7w6xeNYi5rx8tPwc353-yMv5LyrwBW8m9wshQ7J3faae402DgayPFZEFtVZ3R0oBHWA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Training of a neural network, demonstrating convergence on high accuracy and low loss. The curves for other networks are similar and so are not shown.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz272fig7.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/130796783/stz272fig7.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz272fig7.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"130796783\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/484/4/10.1093_mnras_stz272/1/stz272fig7.jpeg?Expires=1611465247&Signature=nulq0VyGUgJ3Lupw8QC~bkcgNQw3~Qqk9F6NAvOPxne9G~ocgRUOHdfqmQ5~vK3OUzSJ0cunTnLy7SxCakFkfZDIGyYMa2eAPrsUCkOywBxuyzSYCyhlM~gRHsPDuycjQTvcMuKTxELrTkRxqC6m2x4XsyZapfdt9KwH5gjrNx1TpVH5DxrzjdHlXoUdbl0DR3Lb8qDAecGPJZyLbGHCwMmtvg8HLRnH52yLIfQq2pOsdJN9otbOnX90wPeeugnvV39AWT-8ynLfRnOWWCi17tTftVoxDtaIEO4XMsk5AUcD6Y8CN-QCHZGBeW29de0tvEyh1M9ZLit5-62mNxpvHw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=130796783&ar=5301418&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz272fig7.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Training of a neural network, demonstrating convergence on high accuracy and low loss. The curves for other networks are similar and so are not shown.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig7\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 7.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/484/4/10.1093_mnras_stz272/1/m_stz272fig7.jpeg?Expires=1611465247&amp;Signature=lMXc7Zye0Bs8~bMVFVh5fD4vSHGh~N~nZotfSytYef6G-LGnFmB6UCeB2NlhUDcD2IkJbwryxcS~mXjMT61Ppk-dBQEfJpaHA2KS3aAxwzUYh3ggk2RQx5f8PiPe7IncaNOoZpVnBKBbIS6DvP-PNMsv6dsyMxH93MSlNF8szEWpb9a7PUnbpgiSDwrJrsVdJj9HkWQgr6m9wGFOF-wSwAzdFV1CyPzefJoyQ0NlteH2y53USs87SAaYv9727Ym~J-hSFm0zD3WiKk1PE9x7w6xeNYi5rx8tPwc353-yMv5LyrwBW8m9wshQ7J3faae402DgayPFZEFtVZ3R0oBHWA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Training of a neural network, demonstrating convergence on high accuracy and low loss. The dashed lines show the value of loss function, evaluated over the image set, and the solid line the classification accuracy. Blue: Loss/accuracy on the training set. Red: Loss/accuracy on validation set of images not used for training. The curves for other networks are similar and so are not shown.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz272fig7.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/130796783/stz272fig7.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz272fig7.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"130796783\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/484/4/10.1093_mnras_stz272/1/stz272fig7.jpeg?Expires=1611465247&Signature=nulq0VyGUgJ3Lupw8QC~bkcgNQw3~Qqk9F6NAvOPxne9G~ocgRUOHdfqmQ5~vK3OUzSJ0cunTnLy7SxCakFkfZDIGyYMa2eAPrsUCkOywBxuyzSYCyhlM~gRHsPDuycjQTvcMuKTxELrTkRxqC6m2x4XsyZapfdt9KwH5gjrNx1TpVH5DxrzjdHlXoUdbl0DR3Lb8qDAecGPJZyLbGHCwMmtvg8HLRnH52yLIfQq2pOsdJN9otbOnX90wPeeugnvV39AWT-8ynLfRnOWWCi17tTftVoxDtaIEO4XMsk5AUcD6Y8CN-QCHZGBeW29de0tvEyh1M9ZLit5-62mNxpvHw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=130796783&ar=5301418&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz272fig7.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Training of a neural network, demonstrating convergence on high accuracy and low loss. The dashed lines show the value of loss function, evaluated over the image set, and the solid line the classification accuracy. Blue: Loss/accuracy on the training set. Red: Loss/accuracy on validation set of images not used for training. The curves for other networks are similar and so are not shown.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">In Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig8\" data-open=\"fig8\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">8</a>, we depict the Receiver Operating Characteristic curve for the first network, trained on simulated lenses and non-lenses, when evaluated on examples not used during training. This figure depicts the trade-off between the true positive rate and the false positive rate achieved for different values of the score threshold. A perfect system would include the point at (0, 1), namely zero false positives and all true positives, and have an area under the curve (AUC) of 1. The AUC is for the first network is 0.9993; for the second, it is 0.9998 and so the curve is not shown.</p>                        <a id=\"130796785\" scrollto-destination=\"130796785\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig8\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 8.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/484/4/10.1093_mnras_stz272/1/m_stz272fig8.jpeg?Expires=1611465247&amp;Signature=vSKbAadrPdCFTqnhqUCakNrVh6d3J3uRRHU5-6FvleFeCViHWR1I6HIR0Zw84SxoqciDQd-JhSnz4MmX7ONf1PIXX1V6vrkFpKq3p3fyrtZLq6aD68WBUCCaICZUnHgRdLqISnD1QJsh0AfcQtYS2OHCOdzsg8xrDYZJwdG1yjJOo3XQpq5hpdgNKJd51BQogxIqVlENQw6i5Le~JF8t2miHWfpc0F-3418TnQe3OM-53FDgnVqyn5VZQ03gvCdeBpelKuOIj9Pc64Y702~SrSJiC9zf0LpcJhCgVDuLo~j99erHw1mhnTbBcs4NdU5jLU8jYQCzYJ0vYbOeBIuwaw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Receiver Operating Characteristic curve for the CNN trained on training set 1, consisting of simulated strong lenses and simulated elliptical galaxies without visible lensing. This curve shows the trade-off between a desired true positive rate and the number of false positives produced by the network for different values of the score threshold. The area under the curve (AUC) for this network is 0.9993. For training set 2, the AUC is 0.9998, so the curve is not shown.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz272fig8.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/130796785/stz272fig8.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz272fig8.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"130796785\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/484/4/10.1093_mnras_stz272/1/stz272fig8.jpeg?Expires=1611465247&Signature=D8qvQk0FlpZtw9sA-rlwZH4RJUHxbdK80HROzUYlIdHeCdOIAAa3KP0R7MhJEadxRjc6-iGvCaN7-UoWdA8nR7nxnVHxcRxkr1IzaTRww~U47TN80cuFgRNtAqSlPFVeC68cxVsnV6nbSN04lFCStZPUj2BxSrWnJ1evdEByr2Ccp21qRZEfFf68gEMSsDCn5rkuEavgFiXiASn~NOPnJNYYYkpK~-zPlnPz4zu-qzv22Jr8at~HQcz96B2awbhFbx7m2FQEhlAck-5TqM0c6vFij2ogbEQn3q7T6NSUVUWb2SPuHv4xLqlvieCmLdNXP~vK2Q7bjaefIDPqONKkLw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=130796785&ar=5301418&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz272fig8.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Receiver Operating Characteristic curve for the CNN trained on training set 1, consisting of simulated strong lenses and simulated elliptical galaxies without visible lensing. This curve shows the trade-off between a desired true positive rate and the number of false positives produced by the network for different values of the score threshold. The area under the curve (AUC) for this network is 0.9993. For training set 2, the AUC is 0.9998, so the curve is not shown.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig8\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 8.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/484/4/10.1093_mnras_stz272/1/m_stz272fig8.jpeg?Expires=1611465247&amp;Signature=vSKbAadrPdCFTqnhqUCakNrVh6d3J3uRRHU5-6FvleFeCViHWR1I6HIR0Zw84SxoqciDQd-JhSnz4MmX7ONf1PIXX1V6vrkFpKq3p3fyrtZLq6aD68WBUCCaICZUnHgRdLqISnD1QJsh0AfcQtYS2OHCOdzsg8xrDYZJwdG1yjJOo3XQpq5hpdgNKJd51BQogxIqVlENQw6i5Le~JF8t2miHWfpc0F-3418TnQe3OM-53FDgnVqyn5VZQ03gvCdeBpelKuOIj9Pc64Y702~SrSJiC9zf0LpcJhCgVDuLo~j99erHw1mhnTbBcs4NdU5jLU8jYQCzYJ0vYbOeBIuwaw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Receiver Operating Characteristic curve for the CNN trained on training set 1, consisting of simulated strong lenses and simulated elliptical galaxies without visible lensing. This curve shows the trade-off between a desired true positive rate and the number of false positives produced by the network for different values of the score threshold. The area under the curve (AUC) for this network is 0.9993. For training set 2, the AUC is 0.9998, so the curve is not shown.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz272fig8.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/130796785/stz272fig8.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz272fig8.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"130796785\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/484/4/10.1093_mnras_stz272/1/stz272fig8.jpeg?Expires=1611465247&Signature=D8qvQk0FlpZtw9sA-rlwZH4RJUHxbdK80HROzUYlIdHeCdOIAAa3KP0R7MhJEadxRjc6-iGvCaN7-UoWdA8nR7nxnVHxcRxkr1IzaTRww~U47TN80cuFgRNtAqSlPFVeC68cxVsnV6nbSN04lFCStZPUj2BxSrWnJ1evdEByr2Ccp21qRZEfFf68gEMSsDCn5rkuEavgFiXiASn~NOPnJNYYYkpK~-zPlnPz4zu-qzv22Jr8at~HQcz96B2awbhFbx7m2FQEhlAck-5TqM0c6vFij2ogbEQn3q7T6NSUVUWb2SPuHv4xLqlvieCmLdNXP~vK2Q7bjaefIDPqONKkLw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=130796785&ar=5301418&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz272fig8.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Receiver Operating Characteristic curve for the CNN trained on training set 1, consisting of simulated strong lenses and simulated elliptical galaxies without visible lensing. This curve shows the trade-off between a desired true positive rate and the number of false positives produced by the network for different values of the score threshold. The area under the curve (AUC) for this network is 0.9993. For training set 2, the AUC is 0.9998, so the curve is not shown.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">The total training time was approximately 40\u00a0h for the first ensemble and 24\u00a0h for the second, trained on an NVidia K80 GPU and Intel Xeon E5-2698 cpu with 12GB RAM and a batch size of 128 images.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=130796787 id=\"130796787\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-2>4.2 Scoring catalogue sources and selecting a candidate set</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Scoring a batch of 128 100x100\u00a0pixel FITS images in three bands took \u223c3\u00a0ms. With the overheads of loading the files into memory, and scoring with 20 networks, scoring the 1 million sources in our catalogue took approximately 6 h. The 254\u00a0GB of images were stored in HDF5 data bases in 15\u00a0GB chunks and the CNNs were able to load the images in batches using the HDF5 files directly, a faster process than working with 1 million or more individual files.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We scored each of the 1.1 million postage stamps with all of the 10 trained networks in each of the two ensembles. We took the mean score from each ensemble to produce two scores for each image. Of the 1061\u00a0868 sources scored by the first ensemble of networks, 576\u00a0025 (54\u00a0per\u2009cent) were scored less than 0.01; and by the second ensemble 967\u00a0348 (91\u00a0per\u2009cent). The first ensemble scored 35\u00a0332 sources above 0.99; the second, only 433. The scores are summarized in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl2\" data-open=\"tbl2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a> and a histogram depicting the distribution of scores is presented in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig9\" data-open=\"fig9\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">9</a>.</p>                        <a id=\"130796790\" scrollto-destination=\"130796790\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig9\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 9.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/484/4/10.1093_mnras_stz272/1/m_stz272fig9.jpeg?Expires=1611465247&amp;Signature=rA9-XDrhHD9GBdiEBYpcvBIXPRSIC~kWy654oDnjI3koo0fyFj0Md1buUOuR3Xt~jkboYU34FjY5a~N9gK9LXs4c9tHdPGz0miS8VHuMBLhVijJ3DrTbKcEWyMK4kGQqSvLhcrhyifc6M1V8RIDfR9XxwG0UXnUtTpOlkDGTQJpXmhtZ-8tjURcNwc2VRYIF4E4XHYPf~khop-Dy1CZoe6FNnirSJRYGR5jffDdF~0XnSQFaH83HiSYhlth4Bqp6yfSRT9bA~alPhRHlRZSAR4fMACAeeOO1JDxfeEoniLZq0XIj5xHRm8smzlHwqacd43PlsJd67dG9Y9G1ghOJWQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Distribution of scores of sources scored by CNNs. For the first ensemble, of 1.1 million sources, 3144 had a score of 1.0 (definitely a lens), 668\u00a0408 had a score &lt; 0.01. For the second, there were no perfect 1.0 scores, and 810\u00a0604 scored &lt; 0.01. There are 358 sources in the final bin with score &gt; 0.98.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz272fig9.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/130796790/stz272fig9.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz272fig9.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"130796790\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/484/4/10.1093_mnras_stz272/1/stz272fig9.jpeg?Expires=1611465247&Signature=aPSADzcXi2We3kD0T0CcC2HkEtoE7myV4aECsQObiGk9H5ty5VoPDy~n0SqU556zA7K42qrGBXD1Xzw1eyEox2Tlhq323-Qcf~UWNMY3UDZtpLGpSbYbh5LO32LXt4NX9zeDQ3BMJaBo335TWEIrdLEm-aWrRfcqZrvHcxiqksvHzIrB5wAxAD36Q4KS4l2qR3C66utegsHVoB~hlEY9Ht9n-arGogut2jVHtJlAoeL4Oktg3tP2842OVmI4wunMhOqJDCTt6Fs3gr7NMg8GdVu4TYtSiWBZJex6IdN3CTugLYGi~1PdS-WaSKLxri4xHKV9uvZB1-fdLgjfW7CRbA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=130796790&ar=5301418&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz272fig9.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Distribution of scores of sources scored by CNNs. For the first ensemble, of 1.1 million sources, 3144 had a score of 1.0 (definitely a lens), 668\u00a0408 had a score &lt; 0.01. For the second, there were no perfect 1.0 scores, and 810\u00a0604 scored &lt; 0.01. There are 358 sources in the final bin with score &gt; 0.98.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig9\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 9.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/484/4/10.1093_mnras_stz272/1/m_stz272fig9.jpeg?Expires=1611465247&amp;Signature=rA9-XDrhHD9GBdiEBYpcvBIXPRSIC~kWy654oDnjI3koo0fyFj0Md1buUOuR3Xt~jkboYU34FjY5a~N9gK9LXs4c9tHdPGz0miS8VHuMBLhVijJ3DrTbKcEWyMK4kGQqSvLhcrhyifc6M1V8RIDfR9XxwG0UXnUtTpOlkDGTQJpXmhtZ-8tjURcNwc2VRYIF4E4XHYPf~khop-Dy1CZoe6FNnirSJRYGR5jffDdF~0XnSQFaH83HiSYhlth4Bqp6yfSRT9bA~alPhRHlRZSAR4fMACAeeOO1JDxfeEoniLZq0XIj5xHRm8smzlHwqacd43PlsJd67dG9Y9G1ghOJWQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Distribution of scores of sources scored by CNNs. There are 358 sources in the final bin with score &gt; 0.98.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz272fig9.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/130796790/stz272fig9.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz272fig9.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"130796790\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/484/4/10.1093_mnras_stz272/1/stz272fig9.jpeg?Expires=1611465247&Signature=aPSADzcXi2We3kD0T0CcC2HkEtoE7myV4aECsQObiGk9H5ty5VoPDy~n0SqU556zA7K42qrGBXD1Xzw1eyEox2Tlhq323-Qcf~UWNMY3UDZtpLGpSbYbh5LO32LXt4NX9zeDQ3BMJaBo335TWEIrdLEm-aWrRfcqZrvHcxiqksvHzIrB5wAxAD36Q4KS4l2qR3C66utegsHVoB~hlEY9Ht9n-arGogut2jVHtJlAoeL4Oktg3tP2842OVmI4wunMhOqJDCTt6Fs3gr7NMg8GdVu4TYtSiWBZJex6IdN3CTugLYGi~1PdS-WaSKLxri4xHKV9uvZB1-fdLgjfW7CRbA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=130796790&ar=5301418&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz272fig9.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Distribution of scores of sources scored by CNNs. For the first ensemble, of 1.1 million sources, 3144 had a score of 1.0 (definitely a lens), 668\u00a0408 had a score &lt; 0.01. For the second, there were no perfect 1.0 scores, and 810\u00a0604 scored &lt; 0.01. There are 358 sources in the final bin with score &gt; 0.98.</p></div></div>                        <a id=\"130796791\" scrollto-destination=\"130796791\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"tbl2\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl2\" data-id=\"tbl2\"><span class=\"label\">Table 2.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Distribution of CNN scores for the two ensembles.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>Score<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Ensemble 1<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Ensemble 2<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>&lt;0.01\u00a0</td><td>576\u00a0025\u00a0</td><td>967\u00a0348\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>&gt;0.5\u00a0</td><td>156\u00a0776\u00a0</td><td>9328\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>&gt;0.99\u00a0</td><td>35\u00a0332\u00a0</td><td>433\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>&gt;0.999\u00a0</td><td>10\u00a0847\u00a0</td><td>97\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-modal\"><table><thead><tr><th>Score<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Ensemble 1<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Ensemble 2<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>&lt;0.01\u00a0</td><td>576\u00a0025\u00a0</td><td>967\u00a0348\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>&gt;0.5\u00a0</td><td>156\u00a0776\u00a0</td><td>9328\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>&gt;0.99\u00a0</td><td>35\u00a0332\u00a0</td><td>433\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>&gt;0.999\u00a0</td><td>10\u00a0847\u00a0</td><td>97\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/130796791\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><div class=\"table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl2\" data-id=\"tbl2\"><span class=\"label\">Table 2.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Distribution of CNN scores for the two ensembles.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>Score<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Ensemble 1<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Ensemble 2<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>&lt;0.01\u00a0</td><td>576\u00a0025\u00a0</td><td>967\u00a0348\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>&gt;0.5\u00a0</td><td>156\u00a0776\u00a0</td><td>9328\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>&gt;0.99\u00a0</td><td>35\u00a0332\u00a0</td><td>433\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>&gt;0.999\u00a0</td><td>10\u00a0847\u00a0</td><td>97\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-modal\"><table><thead><tr><th>Score<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Ensemble 1<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Ensemble 2<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>&lt;0.01\u00a0</td><td>576\u00a0025\u00a0</td><td>967\u00a0348\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>&gt;0.5\u00a0</td><td>156\u00a0776\u00a0</td><td>9328\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>&gt;0.99\u00a0</td><td>35\u00a0332\u00a0</td><td>433\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>&gt;0.999\u00a0</td><td>10\u00a0847\u00a0</td><td>97\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/130796791\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">Due to the subtleties of lensing morphology in this redshift range, and the large number of sources evaluated, false positives are a concern. We wish to produce a candidate set for visual inspection that is as small (pure) as possible whilst containing the majority of the detectable strong lenses in the survey (high completeness). As the discoverable lenses are not known a priori, evaluating completeness is only possible in approximation and after evaluation by eye has been completed (see Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5\"></span><a href=\"#sec5\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">5</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We choose candidates for visual inspection by selecting score thresholds and examining candidates that scored higher than this number by the networks. The thresholds <em>t</em><sub>1</sub> and <em>t</em><sub>2</sub> are free parameters: the scores <em>s</em><sub>1</sub> and <em>s</em><sub>2</sub> are output by the two CNN networks for each source tested. We examine candidates where, for that source, <em>s</em><sub>1</sub> &gt; <em>t</em><sub>1</sub> and <em>s</em><sub>2</sub> &gt; <em>t</em><sub>2</sub>. This filters many sources scored highly by one network but not the other.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We examine candidate sets as per Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl3\" data-open=\"tbl3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a>. With thresholds (0.65, 0.1), we obtain 3582 images to examine; with threshold (0.9999, 0), a further 1841 candidates; and in the area of the extended catalogue, 1878 images with thresholds (0.95, 0.55) for a total of 7301 images. We choose these candidate sets so as to explore the relative contribution of the two CNN ensembles whilst returning a manageable number of candidates. Following inspection of these candidates, author CJ examines a further 9428 candidates with scores above thresholds (0.999, 0) for a total of 16\u00a0729 images. The set with scores (0, 0.999) contained only 49 images, all false positives.</p>                        <a id=\"130796795\" scrollto-destination=\"130796795\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"tbl3\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl3\" data-id=\"tbl3\"><span class=\"label\">Table 3.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Summary of candidate sets examined. These candidate sets were selected by the neural networks with scores greater than the thresholds <em>t</em><sub>1</sub> and <em>t</em><sub>2</sub> and examined by the authors. New candidates indicates candidates that are unique to that search; search 4 contained 22 candidates, but only four that were not found in the other searches, demonstrating the rapidly diminishing returns. Searches 1, 2, and 4 were applied to the larger source catalogue, search 3 was applied to the extended catalogue only, as described in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3-1\"></span><a href=\"#sec3-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">3.1</a>.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>Search<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Size<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>t</em><sub>1</sub><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>t</em><sub>2</sub><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Candidates \u2265\u00a02<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>New candidates<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Purity (per cent)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Search 1\u00a0</td><td>3582\u00a0</td><td>0.65\u00a0</td><td>0.1\u00a0</td><td>11\u00a0</td><td>43\u00a0</td><td>1.2\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Search 2\u00a0</td><td>1841\u00a0</td><td>0.9999\u00a0</td><td>0.0\u00a0</td><td>5\u00a0</td><td>15\u00a0</td><td>0.8\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Search 3\u00a0</td><td>1878\u00a0</td><td>0.95\u00a0</td><td>0.55\u00a0</td><td>6\u00a0</td><td>21\u00a0</td><td>1.1\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Search 4\u00a0</td><td>9428\u00a0</td><td>0.999\u00a0</td><td>0.0\u00a0</td><td>3\u00a0</td><td>4\u00a0</td><td>0.04\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-modal\"><table><thead><tr><th>Search<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Size<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>t</em><sub>1</sub><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>t</em><sub>2</sub><span  \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/130796795\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><div class=\"table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl3\" data-id=\"tbl3\"><span class=\"label\">Table 3.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Summary of candidate sets examined. These candidate sets were selected by the neural networks with scores greater than the thresholds <em>t</em><sub>1</sub> and <em>t</em><sub>2</sub> and examined by the authors. New candidates indicates candidates that are unique to that search; search 4 contained 22 candidates, but only four that were not found in the other searches, demonstrating the rapidly diminishing returns. Searches 1, 2, and 4 were applied to the larger source catalogue, search 3 was applied to the extended catalogue only, as described in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3-1\"></span><a href=\"#sec3-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">3.1</a>.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>Search<span aria-hidden=\"true\" <h3 scrollto-destination=130796796 id=\"130796796\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-3>4.3 Examining candidate lenses</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Of 16\u00a0729 examined candidates, 250 had a grade &gt; 0, 87 \u22651, and 29 \u2265 2. With grade 0 candidates, we have an overall false-positive rate (false positives \u00a0=\u00a0highly scored non-lenses) of 98.5\u00a0per\u2009cent amongst the candidates we reviewed. Of the candidate sets we reviewed, the purest was the 3582 candidates with scores <em>s</em><sub>1</sub> &gt; 0.65 and <em>s</em><sub>2</sub> &gt; 0.1, which yielded 43 candidates with grades &gt; 1 for all examiners. Overall time taken to examine candidates is approximately 5\u00a0h of astronomer time. Of the 87 candidates identified with scores \u22651, 4 are known from a previous search (Diehl et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib20\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib20\" data-open=\"bib20\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The lenses with a grade \u22652 are presented in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig11\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig11\" data-open=\"fig11\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">10</a> and those with 1 \u2265 grade &lt; 2 are shown in Figs <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig12\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig12\" data-open=\"fig12\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">11</a> and\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig13\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig13\" data-open=\"fig13\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">12</a>. The candidates are summarized in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl4\" data-open=\"tbl4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a>, including with the photometric redshifts for the lenses with 2\u03c3 errors estimated by <span class=\"small-caps\">bpz</span>.</p>                        <a id=\"130796799\" scrollto-destination=\"130796799\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig11\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 10.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/484/4/10.1093_mnras_stz272/1/m_stz272fig11.jpeg?Expires=1611465247&amp;Signature=UV6CFzPdqSAL1cWVXabiaF9PsprTzzD4X6xnlTfiOtH4Idlz7VGkukocvYyPPg7l6200XbZawZ4U-ru8jrq2rkm2oS9m~EILLDbw2hZhfwT69npL9wwVz0WOsLXri9nWyJU93RmKWd7CQGxffs1hcYZaxpCLE8P~HBVgAgphnewoJ35KCEors64gNEPdeGoSp2i~05qUUYsk99I9s7dsSVhD8az4k2TEDia~gxJO5L4NSDdLRaPeWYDF~NZXn7TsYxUe3DUkr3Zm0UVsEEtGx4NrB-hpmRzI0QJjU1EdWVE8TFx9iIhkTtnhmQ754eWt4EQbEU0V0KaUTQeRDiWMLA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"26 new lens candidates, with a grade \u22652, discovered in DES imaging data using CNNs. class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/130796802\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">The scores the candidate lenses received from the networks are presented in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig10\" data-open=\"fig10\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">13</a>. Most candidates received scores of approximately 1.0 from the CNN trained on simulations, but were more evenly distributed in their scores from the second CNN trained on simulations and real galaxies. There is no significant difference in CNN scores by grade of lens candidate. The mean scores for candidates of grade 2+\u00a0were 0.97 and 0.39 for the two networks; for grade &lt;2, the mean scores were 0.87 and 0.42, respectively.</p>                        <a id=\"130796804\" scrollto-destination=\"130796804\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig10\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 13.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/484/4/10.1093_mnras_stz272/1/m_stz272fig10.jpeg?Expires=1611465247&amp;Signature=JyjqWUxDDWePzPNCkV7lTRJaMWCCuEgnTQIserYIeS6v08ITm7VU~MjQ4fhH1QD8JyCpYlZ3w-q4HMpeXf1yUdDnHI5MxN2Uc~zqTlAP4nnimL-iLYpxZz6gzmhzj-6gUfR8S71JVVkeqbgTRSA58Di7jazq4IYvWh8QI8edHsqQuW~gvW2M6wJ3vTDp-qo0rOCJENSiYapFpAHbffqUq0z--HvDY81bfPLJsRSGQomrfjbs6jb5IyBx93haQiqz-0F0zoyUQgMKm~ynacxfVDxwTr4Sc1gsPxU7Y3w4W12VaDqxbNEW783beV33ngHEjKoDCZlFi9n8rMKCeRX0eg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Scores received from the CNNs by the most highly graded lens candidates.
